Award.AwardTitle: All-Electrochemical Synthesis of Nanoporous Metal Based Catalysts for Energy Applications and Environmental Pollution Remedy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Chemical Catalysis Program supports the efforts of Professor Nikolay Dimitrov at the State University of New York at Binghamton to design and develop an all-electrochemical synthetic approach that enables the production of thin and continuous nanoporous catalysts with tunable thickness and interconnected porosity. The synthetic protocols include electrodeposition of continuous single-phase alloy films followed by selective oxidative removal of the less-noble component (de-alloying). The de-alloying process completes the fabrication of nanoporous metals (NPMs) with thicknesses of less than 20 nm. The synthetic method results in reliable composition control and high processing efficiency. During different stages of the fabrication, the catalyst surface area, structure and composition are confirmed by electrochemical methods, and also by STM/AFM, SEM, and EDS. The NPMs are then either used directly as catalysts or are electrochemically functionalized with a sub-nanometer thick layer of catalytically active metals or alloys. The coating is made by state-of-the art electrochemical approaches, ensuring complete and uniform coverage over the NPM matrix. The catalysts are assessed for activity and durability in established lab tests for the oxygen reduction reaction, organic fuel oxidation, and/or nitrate electro-reduction. The best catalysts are then assessed in a semi-industrial environment. Qualified undergraduates from underrepresented groups are offered summer research activities in the investigator?s research group.

The NSF Chemical Catalysis Program supports the efforts of Professor Nikolay Dimitrov at the State University of New York at Binghamton to introduce an all-electrochemical synthetic approach for the fabrication of a new class of catalytically active materials based on nanoporous metals as an alternative to the most established nanoparticle catalysts for energy and environmental applications. Chemical methods of synthesis are sometimes problematic as they can produce by-products and inhibitors to catalytic activity, that must be removed by the use of additional chemicals and costly procedures. One advantage of the electrochemical fabrication of catalysts is that it introduces a higher level of control and environmentally friendly routines. Such approaches rely on metal(s) reduction performed by applying voltage or current so that further treatment and/or removal of unwanted chemicals or contaminants is not needed. The catalysts designed and fabricated in this research will be used for industrially-important catalytic reactions related to fuel cell applications and environmental remediation. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in advanced materials processing, along with analytical and characterizational methods at the interface between chemistry and materials science.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The main emphasis over the project?s duration of 5 calendar years has been on comprehensive studies and development of a method that employs all-electrochemical routes for synthesis of active and durable catalysts with application in energy harvesting and environmental polution remediation. This activity led to the successful development of nanoporus gold (NPG) catalyst cariers obtained by de-alloying of pre-deposited Au-Ag and Au-Cu alloys. The research in this trust was focused on the understanding of Cu-Au thin film de-alloying and on optimization of thickness and composition of the precursor alloy for synthesizing uniform and continuous NPG layer on metal surfaces. A key effort was also made at preserving the continuity and providing for the NPG layers well adhering when deposited on C-based surfaces. Results of this trust were disseminated by five research papers, four invited presentations, five conference talks, and two PhD dissertations. Another direction pursued was the NPG carrier coating (functionalization) with continuous and uniform, catalytically active layers. The coatings were deposited by techniques that promote growth of continuous and commensurate layers with the substrate, like surface limited redox replacement (SLRR) with and without potential control, as well as spontaneous thin film deposition. Main focus in this trust was the SLRR deposition of Pd, the electroless SLRR growth of Pt, and the SLRR growth of Au-Cu alloys. Key achievements are the controlled SLRR deposition of Pd using of both adsorbed and absorbed hydrogen as well as the development of approaches that prevent the growth mode transitioning to diffusion limitations during SLRR deposition in one call. The deposition effort was also accompanied with performance tests in formic acid oxidation and nitrate electroreduction reactions, assessing the activity and durability of accordingly synthesized thin film catalysts. Results of the SLRR developments and catalytic testing have been disseminated by ten research papers, one keynote, four invited presentations, seven conference talks, and two PhD dissertations.

In a more applied twist of this project a successful comprehensive routine was developed for fabrication of glass interposers with application in 2.5D and 3D packaging in electronic industry. The activity was mostly focused on perfecting the superconformal deposition of Cu in through glass holes (TGH) with generating virtually negligible coverage on the flat glass surface. A complementary effort was aimed at pre-coating of the starting bare glass surface along with TGHs with a conductive seed layer that serves as substrate for the following Cu electrodeposition process. Key achievements of this part of our project was the development of the hybrid method for generating a seed conductive layer and the development of defect-free, fastest yet, and cost-effective superconformal filling with Cu of TGHs with aspect ratio 6 and 10 using the additive MTT. The findings of this applied activity have been disseminated in five research papers, two full-text peer-reviewed conference papers, six invited presentation, eight conference talks, and two PhD dissertations.

Broader Impact: The main project developmental effort has greatly contributed in the improvement and optimization of lab-scale of functionalized catalysts for various applications. The applied component focused on the development of glass interposers led to substantial interest of our major industrial sponsor and collaborator Corning Inc resulting in exploration of potential technology transfer. Key findings of various aspects of this project were published in a PI's review paper in the journal Electrochimica Acta and in a featured article in the leading Electrochemical Society magazine, ECS INTERFACE.

The project impacted substantially the professional development of a variety of people. Among those, the leadership and/or participation in related activities was instrumental (i) for the PI's promotion to full professor, (ii) for the graduation of four students with Ph.D. degree and for major progress to Ph.D. of another two. The project also prepared professionally two students with M.S. degree, and two undergraduate students with B.S. degree with Honors Thesis. REU support helped a first-generation-in-college student to find a competitive job after graduation. Additional NSF support provided to a graduate student for an internship with NIST was instrumental for his receiving of the prestigious NRC fellowship for two-year postdoctoral appointment. Finally, female graduate student supported also by the Clark Fellowship for minority students was involved in early stages of the project.

Two educational components associated with electrochemical synthesis of catalysts and their testing/characterization were successfully developed and implemented in three courses in the chemistry and materials science curriculum. The project sponsored fully or partially seven graduate students for a semester or more, two undergraduate students for a summer or more, the PI for a month each summer of the project duration. A postdoctoral researcher, graduate and undergraduate students in PI's group participated at international meetings of the Electrochemical Society and International Society of Electrochemistry, regional meetings of American Chemical Society, and Gordon Research Conferences, partially or fully supported by the project funds.


Last Modified: 12/06/2018
Modified by: Nikolay Dimitrov
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit: The main emphasis over the project?s duration of 5 calendar years has been on comprehensive studies and development of a method that employs all-electrochemical routes for synthesis of active and durable catalysts with application in energy harvesting and environmental polution remediation. This activity led to the successful development of nanoporus gold (NPG) catalyst cariers obtained by de-alloying of pre-deposited Au-Ag and Au-Cu alloys. The research in this trust was focused on the understanding of Cu-Au thin film de-alloying and on optimization of thickness and composition of the precursor alloy for synthesizing uniform and continuous NPG layer on metal surfaces. A key effort was also made at preserving the continuity and providing for the NPG layers well adhering when deposited on C-based surfaces. Results of this trust were disseminated by five research papers, four invited presentations, five conference talks, and two PhD dissertations. Another direction pursued was the NPG carrier coating (functionalization) with continuous and uniform, catalytically active layers. Main focus in this trust was the SLRR deposition of Pd, the electroless SLRR growth of Pt, and the SLRR growth of Au-Cu alloys. The deposition effort was also accompanied with performance tests in formic acid oxidation and nitrate electroreduction reactions, assessing the activity and durability of accordingly synthesized thin film catalysts. In a more applied twist of this project a successful comprehensive routine was developed for fabrication of glass interposers with application in 2.5D and 3D packaging in electronic industry. Key achievements of this part of our project was the development of the hybrid method for generating a seed conductive layer and the development of defect-free, fastest yet, and cost-effective superconformal filling with Cu of TGHs with aspect ratio 6 and 10 using the additive MTT. The findings of this applied activity have been disseminated in five research papers, two full-text peer-reviewed conference papers, six invited presentation, eight conference talks, and two PhD dissertations. The project impacted substantially the professional development of a variety of people. Among those, the leadership and/or participation in related activities was instrumental (i) for the PI's promotion to full professor, (ii) for the graduation of four students with Ph.D. degree and for major progress to Ph.D. of another two. The project also prepared professionally two students with M.S. degree, and two undergraduate students with B.S. degree with Honors Thesis. REU support helped a first-generation-in-college student to find a competitive job after graduation. Additional NSF support provided to a graduate student for an internship with NIST was instrumental for his receiving of the prestigious NRC fellowship for two-year postdoctoral appointment. Finally, female graduate student supported also by the Clark Fellowship for minority students was involved in early stages of the project. Two educational components associated with electrochemical synthesis of catalysts and their testing/characterization were successfully developed and implemented in three courses in the chemistry and materials science curriculum. The project sponsored fully or partially seven graduate students for a semester or more, two undergraduate students for a summer or more, the PI for a month each summer of the project duration. A postdoctoral researcher, graduate and undergraduate students in PI's group participated at international meetings of the Electrochemical Society and International Society of Electrochemistry, regional meetings of American Chemical Society, and Gordon Research Conferences, partially or fully supported by the project funds.
